results.title: An Officer and a gentleman
results.creator_credit: Taylor Hackford, Martin Elfand, Lorimar Film Entertainment and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Taylor Hackford (Against all odds, Proof of life) directed “An Officer and a gentleman”, starring Richard Gere and Debra Winger. It is the story of Zack Mayo (Gere) a man of uncertain future who is in conflict with his identity. A life of familial instability has left Zack unwilling to engage emotionally with others, especially women. Zack determines that he favours a career as a navy pilot, largely to prove to his alcoholic father that he is a son worthy of respect and capable of achievement. His steely demeanour suits military life but is in part broken down by his romance with a local factory girl Paula Pokrifi (Winger). Life in the armed forces is depicted as brutal and inhumane as the recruits make their way through a gruelling 13-week course. Foley, (Louis Gossett, Jnr) the irascible Major in charge of the recruits, rides Mayo particularly hard as he recognises in him Officer material. Mayo is torn between his cold conduct that shelters him from feeling anything and his burgeoning love for Paula. “An Officer and a gentleman” won Oscars for Gosset (Best Supporting Actor) and Best Song for “Up where we belong”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Taylor Hackford, Martin Elfand, Lorimar Film Entertainment and Paramount Pictures

results.title: An Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridge
results.creator_credit: Paul de Roubaix, Marcel Ichac, Robert Enrico, Films du Centaure and Filmartic
results.brief_description: A dramatisation of a short story by Ambrose Bierce set during the American Civil War in which a Confederate citizen stands on the scaffold, about to be hanged, and seems, as by a series of miracles, to escape death.

results.title: An Introduction to the defence cataloguing system
results.creator_credit: Yoram Gross, Frank Bagnall, Film Australia and Yoram Gross Films
results.brief_description: Modern warfare involving greater man power and more complex weaponry creates greater problems of supply. Efficient supply management is essential. A common supply language has been devised enabling items to be easily found.

results.title: An Introduction to the art of figure skating
results.creator_credit: Sydney Newman and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The fundamentals of figure skating are demonstrated by world champion Barbara Ann Scott and coach and judge Melville Rogers. A brief discussion of edges and basic figures is followed by an analysis of a number of complex turns. The importance of balance, body, and limbs is explained.

results.title: An Interview with Jan McCarthy
results.brief_description: Jan McCarthy traces her career path of nursing, how it took her overseas and her time in the army, posted in Vietnam and Singapore. In Singapore, McCarthy became a Major and was later promoted to Colonel. She has no regrets about serving in the army and sees it as one big family.

results.title: An Interview with George Derham
results.creator_credit: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: George Derham was called up to serve for Australia on the 4/4/44. He joined the Australian Navy and recalls his time there, of fitting in and standing out. Collecting Australian prisoners of war in Japan, two images affected Derham greatly - that of Tokyo after the extensive firebombing by the US, and the emaciated state of the prisoners of war. Despite this, Derham sees military life as a valuable part of his development and works hard to assist returned soldiers and their families.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Derham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.brief_description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

results.title: An Interview with Jack Jones
results.brief_description: Born in Ascot Vale, Jack Jones was only fifteen when Menzies declared war so he had to wait till 1942 before he could sign up. Put through extensive training he was posted in New Guinea and, later, Bougainville, where they had to wait for four months after the war ended to be brought home. While some of his colleagues went ‘troppo’, Jones coped by seeing his time in the war as a job.

results.title: An Interview with Peter Clemence
results.brief_description: Peter Clemence tells us his experience in the Royal Australian Air Force at the end of the Second World War, his experiences flying scientists in Antarctica in the 1950’s and his adventures flying helicopters during the mining exploration era. He also talks about Ash Wednesday and the collapse of the West Gate Bridge.

results.title: An Interview with Harold Brown
results.brief_description: Harold Brown reflects fondly on his time in the army. Joining the artillery division in 1942, he was posted to Bougainville, where disease was more of a threat to the soldiers than the Japanese. Despite longing to be back home with his newborn son, Brown could not have wished to be with a better crew.
